Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: Not that much of anything.
Hopefully something for the MCAT, time will tell
I learned a bunch of E&M concepts. I also learned how to manage my time and survive this class.
Integrating life science topics to real world physics applications.
I continued honing my skills in physics that I began learning in PHYS 170.
I learned how to solve some physics problems.
I learned about electricity and magnetism
Learned about circuit elements.
I learned how to reason about physics phenomena and solve physics problems.

I learned critical problem solving abilities and understood physics on a much better level. This and PHYS 170 greatly upped my confidence in STEM and my experience in the 170/171 - I highly recommend this sequence. These classes have been much better than any bio/chem class I've taken, and I wish bio/chem classes learn from how Daisuke and Simon value students and their learning.
I learned a lot about different physics concepts and it gave me a broad overview of the subject.
I was able to think like a physicist and solve physics problems throughout the course by using logical reasoning and mathematical concepts.
Biological applications to physics.

Developed some basic skills in electricity & magnetism  about what youd expect from an intro E&M course. Did not remotely deliver on the purported life sciences connections. Im fine with taking a straight up E&M course but wouldnt have minded more truth in advertising. The promises to learn to think like a physicist seemed hollow. I mainly learned to memorize procedures for different types of problems, which isnt really much more substantial than rote memorization of equations.

I learned about physics - from mechanics to electromagnetism. I learned about making friends, working collaboratively, believing in myself, and tackling problems that at first seem daunting. I learned how to puzzle my way through each physic problem by visualizing it and using overarching principles to guide my step-by-step logic. I also became more confident with math/science problems.
Think like a physicist

This course revolves around Maxwell's equations, the fundamental physical insight of the 19th century that relates electric and magnetic forces. You learn how to think about such forces and use the equations in fairly simple, straightforward situations. The first month of the class goes over simple harmonic oscillators (waves), the middle bulk of the class goes over the Maxwells equations (with detours into different types of circuits) and the last couple of classes go over quantum wave theory and the Schrodinger's equation in brief. While not a super rigorous explication of E&M, the class serves as a great introduction into some big ideas in physics.

This is the best STEM class that I've taken thus far at Yale, and the style of teaching, encouraged collaboration, and support have made all the difference in my confidence as a student pursuing pre-med. I finally learned how to effectively problem solve, attack problems despite its difficulty, as well as study in a correct and efficient manner. Definitely take this course.
We learned predominantly about Maxwell's equations in the context of different waves.
I learned the electricity and magnetism concepts of introductory physics.
I learned some of the basics of physics.

I learned the basics of electricity and magnetism and how to solve relevant problems. One of my biggest takeaways from this class, though, was how to be determined and push through a problem even when I didn't understand it at first and it was really, really challenging.
Electricity, magnetism, circuits.
This class was really not good
thinking like a physicist

This course is a solid foundation in simple harmonic waves, electricity (circuits!), magnetism, optics, and even quantum mechanics. While there are many fewer applications to the life sciences this semester, it is still an excellent course. It is highly collaborative and engaging. This class has inspired a deep love and appreciation of physics in me!
I learned about springs, resistors, Faraday's law, Amphere's law, and other topics related to electricity and magnetism.

Honestly, the teacher was so confusing, I don't think I learned much of anything. But, I definitely learned how to teach myself and ask for help as a result of this class. If you're taking this course as a pre-med, good luck and don't expect to learn much of anything.
I learned how to better apply my physics skills, and learned a lot more about the physical world.

Strengths: This course fosters community through a shared negative experience (but a lovely community nonetheless). It's not that difficult, but it's a step up from last semester, and Daisuke is a lot less forgiving than Simon was. The problem sets were easier, but the exams were probably a little harder. I really appreciated all the different levels of support and how frequently available office hours and study halls were.
Weaknesses: The lectures were not great. Daisuke could have made the material a lot more engaging through demos or through more problem solving. He spent a ton of time every single class on logistics (like when the next study hall would be (it was the same schedule every week)) and then often rushed right through all the actual content. He had a hard time answering students' questions and wasn't that responsive/didn't make real adjustments to his pace or teaching style when it was clear we didn't understand (which he could confirm very easily from polling questions or actual questions). There was very little material applicable to life science this semester, which helped a lot last semester in terms of understanding the material conceptually, and there was very little emphasis on problem solving skills.

Good modules, but overall the workload is just grossly disproportional compared to the amount required for other classes. If every class had the amount of work that physics profs somehow feel they are entitled to assign then it would be physically impossible to complete all the work needed in a semester.

Daisuke is an understanding professor, but often one that puts too much on his students. If you are open and talk to him during class about difficulty, he'll try to adjust. 

PSETs need to be reworked, only a few of the questions feel relevant, the rest seem out-of-nowhere. I feel like I learn the PSETs in retrospect because there's so much thrown at you to begin with. Some end up being very helpful for exams; graded PSETs should focus on these, in my opinion.

Quiz system (with a few group quizzes and 3 drops) is perfect, I'd say. 

Exams are typically fair, though on the difficult side.
This class was exhausting. However, you are supported by a dedicated staff of TAs, peer tutors, and the professor. Students also support each other which is great.

Strength: clear instruction and strong support for students. 

Weakness: none
Overall, this was a good course. The workload was high, but manageable. I am very glad I took 171 over 181 because I feel as though I was able to manage this course much easier.

A strength of this course is study hall and the peer tutors. They are really helpful and great! The module notes are also very helpful and (in my opinion) way more convenient and straightforward to deal with than a whole textbook. A weakness would basically be almost everything else. The class was unorganized and confusing, the material was not well taught, and the experience was overall a little frustrating. I still think this is a better option than the 180/181 sequence if you're pre-med and just need to take physics, because there is no question that the 180/181 material is way more difficult, and the 180/181 psets are much longer. That being said, in no way did I enjoy this class. Daisuke does not explain concepts clearly, and I've had to consistently learn everything from reading the modules on my own because I don't understand anything from lecture, which is a frustrating experience. I also feel like the course generally tries to incorporate higher level concepts on a very surface level (like eigenvalues/eigenvectors) without teaching the full math behind them, which makes it really hard for me to fully understand what I'm learning and why. The Monday quizzes were also kind of dumb hard this semester if I'm being honest. Just unnecessary! And I still don't understand why they changed the grading policy from being able to get 40% of missed points back on midterms with corrections in 170, to just 30% in 171. That just seemed like an arbitrary change and was pretty annoying.
The strengths were the other students and the TAs and peer tutors.

Strengths: Daisuke is a really supportive and sweet professor, exams are fair because they are similar to psets and practice exams, very collaborative environment, you are rewarded for your hard work 
Weaknesses: sometimes Daisuke would spend too much time in the beginning of lecture talking about broad topics, but I preferred it if he spent more time doing clicker questions
Problem sets help advance understanding. Lectures were a repeat of the module notes and did not expand knowledge or explicate material further.

Strengths: well organized. good/ relevant content

weaknesseS: extremely time consuming. professor diasuke didn't have official office hours or come to study hall so I didn't get to discuss my questions with him as often as I would have liked to.
I think this course was excellent in facilitating collaborative work.

Strengths are that it is conducive to a collaborative learning community for students, daisuke is very friendly and warm and always makes himself available for students (out of all the STEM professors I've had, he and Simon have cared the most about students)

Weaknesses - quizzes are very difficult and at times could be unreasonable, one of the midterms was very difficult, and sometimes I felt that the concepts were not well-explained, especially when we were on the modules dealing with gauss's law and ampere's law

Not all, but a good portion of the psets were overly long and hard. They didn't accurately reflect what we'd been doing in class, so we were often unprepared. This was a bigger problem in 170 and not 171, but it was still true. The Monday quizzes were helpful to keep up to date on things.

Strengths:
- Peer Tutors, TAs, Professor's Office Hours
- reasonable workload for psets near exam times

Weaknesses:
- course material was not well taught all the time and the module was not helpful in clarifying concepts
Strengths are the TAs and the community centered aspect of the course.

This was not a very well-run or well-taught course. The lectures started off dull, and grew increasingly weak, disorganized, and incomprehensible. There was no reason to pay attention in class because doing so never got me anywhere. All the learning happens in study hall and with friends or peer tutors. Problem sets were shorter but quizzes and midterms were harder, and while its not that hard to get a decent grade, the fact was that the lecture content, modules, psets, quizzes, and exams all tested different things, and a lot of preparation was not necessarily rewarded, as it was in 170. Its not a mean-spirited intro class, but its a slog, and altogether weaker than first semester. The lecturing in particular needs a ton of work.

Strengths: COLLABORATIVE ENVIRONMENT. I cannot stress enough what a difference this has made in the learning experience for all students. Not only are we NOT graded on a CURVE (against each other), but it is also clear that the PROFESSOR, TEACHING FELLOWS, AND PEER TUTORS all care about the success of the students, and are willing to take the time and energy to help them as much as they can.  We are all on the SAME TEAM! I seriously hope all STEM courses, especially PRE-MED courses can learn from this course, and try to model their courses after it (in the ways that are applicable for the respective fields). This course has by a LANDSLIDE been my BEST experience in STEM at Yale thus far. And this course was no easier than other STEM courses -- in fact, I think it was much more intellectually challenging than some others!
Format of course with lecture and study hall is really good

I appreciated how the material was structured, starting with simple oscillators, learning about electricity and magnetism, and then returning to learn about electromagnetic waves which have both fluctuating electric and magnetic fields. I wished more time was spent on the last part, learning more about the Schrodinger equation and quantum mechanics, but there simply wasn't enough time. I never felt like I truly understood the wave equation, just knew how to apply it in limited circumstances. Otherwise, the class was interesting, fair, and rewarding. If you've taken MATH120 you will probably find this class pretty easy since most of the conceptual work is figuring out how to take certain types of integrals in different situations.

Strengths: peer tutors and study hall
Weaknesses: poll everywhere

The presentations during class moved along far too quickly without giving me a chance to process what was going on. However, the TAs and ULAs readily made themselves available for questions, as well as Professor Nagai.
I like the study hall hours. I feel as though the course itself can cover more example problems in class and less theory.

It covers a lot of material, but honestly the topics aren't taught well and students struggle to keep up. They end up learning all the material in study halls with the TAs doing the psets rather then in lecture. and the professor didn't even show up to the study halls. Considering his office hours were during the day, some people couldn't make them so coming to study hall would have been helpful.

A strength of the course is that the weekly problem sets and quizzes as well as the 2 midterms helped me stay on top of the material. I would have appreciated learning more about how the things we learned could be applied to situations we might actually encounter in life or phenomena that was less abstract.
Lectures were not very clear - I ended up having to do a lot of learning on my own. But peer tutors are very helpful and basically got me through the course.
great TAs, student tutors and instructor!

I thought the problem sets took less time this semester, and they were more straightforward. The course is well structured and organized. The course also has ample resources to help students if they are struggling. The modules, unfortunately, were less cohesive this semester and I used them less as a study tool. Instead, I used practice questions and questions from the problem sets.

Strengths: There is a lot of support and help for this course. Daisuke and the TA/Peer tutor team have a lot of office hours and study hall sessions to help you with psets and general conceptual understanding of concepts. I think the quizzes were a great way to keep up with the course content and to make sure that we have a good conceptual understanding of what was covered. 
Weakness: The quizzes toward the end of the semester were a lot more difficult than what was covered in the lecture, and I felt less prepared for those. Lecture at times felt a little rushed towards the end.

The exams and homework for this course was structured much more reasonably than for 180/181. At the beginning of the semester the lectures were almost painfully slow, but overall the course is not bad. The exam re-grading process is really strange and i would much prefer to have students re-do the problems correctly than the strange problem evaluation system they have going on now. As it stands exam corrections were very obscure and i heard from several students that hardly anyone got any points back at all.

I will say that the organization of the course made a little more sense than PHYS 170, but there were definitely modules that made no sense to be included. For one, the inclusion of quantum mechanics (especially the style in which it was presented) made no sense for us to learn, especially in the last days of class. However, the worst part about this course had to be the professor. In my experience in STEM intro classes here at Yale, the only professor who was worse as a teacher was Alanna Schepartz for organic chemistry.
This course was probably all strengths. It was the best introductory STEM class I have taken so far.

Quizzes varied hugely in difficulty, from unreasonably hard to extremely easy. A better attempt to regulate this would have helped. The lectures were a bit dry: more pictures maybe? Otherwise relatively well taught for the material at hand.

If you're taking this, it's probably because you have to. Compared to 180/181, this sequence is a lot easier in terms of intellectual challenge but has more busy work and worse professors (Steinacker is universally loved, so a difficult comparison, but still). You'll probably end up with the same grade because of the respective curves, so just choose based on the experience you want to have.
Take it if you have to, but the workload is unreasonable.

Yes, though I'm less sure of how I felt about 170 vs 180, the material is more similar between the second semesters of the two courses. For low physics background, I still think this sequence is the move. I really appreciated its break from typical physics (never took AP Phys).
Only if you need it.
No
Definitely! Great selection over 180/181. Needed for premed and MCDB.

I would definitely recommend 170/171 over 180/181 for anyone who is not super interested/well-versed in mathematics. I really enjoyed this sequence overall, and found it to be much more manageable, especially as a pre-med student. The professor was very kind and passionate, and the teaching staff was amazing. Overall, this is the best intro physics could get!
Only if you have to.

Take this over PHYS 180/181 if you're a biology person/ if you don't like math/if this is your first time taking physics because most of the people in this class are like that and its a supportive environment
As a requirement
No
I would only recommend this course to students who have to take it.

Yes! Highly recommend the 170/171 sequence. I never realized how much I would love physics and am even considering taking more math/physics classes now after thinking that I wasn't suited for it. I loved my experience and have made many friends who have helped me immensely this year.
I'd probably recommend it over 180/181 since it was slightly easier and the final was much more reasonable.

If you're looking at PHYS 171 or 181, chances are you have to take either one of them. 171 has less advanced math concepts that you have to apply to solve the physics problems, so I'd recommend it if you aren't into math that much.
Yes I would. This has been one of my favorite Yale classes.

Not by any means would I recommend this for fun, but as a prerequisite, youll live. 181 seems to be better-taught by a mile, but the lack of curve in 171 is a perk, as is study hall. Take whichever one your friends take and youll be infinitely happier.

If pre-med students are looking for a physics course, THIS IS THE ONE TO TAKE! I cannot emphasize it enough. You will need to put in the work, but you will get rewarded for it. All resources for your success are within reach. This class has even felt like a family at times. If you put yourself out there, you can make a lot of friends, or you can solidify the friendships you already have. Regardless, the experience will undoubtedly bond you. Take this one if you are a pre-med student who wants to avoid a competitive climate and still learn a lot of physics (prepare yourself for a very challenging course, but it can be so rewarding!).
Its not bad take this over 180 for sure
Not as good as physics 170 but still a very interesting course

If you like math and physics then you should definitely take the class, although you might want to consider a more rigorous introduction into physics. If you did well in MATH 120 you will probably find this class easy since most of the conceptual work is figuring out how to take certain types of integrals in different situations. Also there are a lot of fun people in class who you end up getting to know through the study halls.

Yes. This was the best STEM class that I've taken at Yale thus far. It was challenging; however, the resources and tools that this class provides (encouraged and plentiful office hours from not only the professor but also numerous TAs, and peer tutors) makes doing well in this class 100% possible. I have learned how to collaborate with my fellow classmates with the aid of incredibly helpful peer tutors, and I have also learned how to seek guidance when the modules and concepts are tough. Despite its difficulty, physics encourages STEM students to believe that they can succeed even when problems are hard to solve.
I would recommend this course over 181 and if you have to take it I would say its not that bad, but I wouldn't recommend if its not a requirement.

It was interesting to see the biological/medicinal applications of physics, so I enjoyed this aspect of the course. However, it was extremely difficult, and the amount we were expected to learn was often overwhelming.
If you have to.
No. Just no. No one deserves this kind of academic torture. Take only if necessary.
It depends on their interests. I am glad I took the course, but it took so much time that there was a big opportunity cost.
Take this over 181. This was not a particularly stressful course, exams are fair and psets are fair.
This class is likely mandatory -- it was somewhat fair, but still not taught well at all.
yes!
yes, I would! Definitely take this course with friends! It will make your learning experience much better.
Absolutely!  If you're a life sciences major (MCDB or E&EB), I would highly recommend this course over PHYS 181. The material is made very accessible to non-physics majors!
Yes, I would recommend this course. The course set up was very similar to 170, so it was a fairly smooth transition from 170 to 171.

You're probably taking this course as a pre-med who has to take physics. Regardless of if you take PHYS 180/181 or PHYS 170/171, physics is going to be another annoying intro course you'll have to get through. The psets will be annoying busy work, and you should go to study halls/office hours to finish them (DO NOT DO THEM ALONE); the quizzes (an aspect exclusive to PHYS 171) will be weird; the midterms/finals will be hard, but they are challenges you just have to get through. If you are choosing between the two, I would just advocate going for a course in which you will have support from friends for studying and doing psets because these courses are a group effort.
If you are looking to learn introductory physics, in my opinion Daisuke is the best person you can learn it from. This was my favorite introductory STEM course so far.

I didn't try very hard in this course, because it was a requirement and I had other priorities. I accepted that I wouldn't get an A, and tried to learn what I could without stressing myself out too much. I would not recommend this course, but it's not awfulthe workload is more reasonable than 170 (although it's possible I only felt that way because of the adjustment I made to my attitude toward the course, which not everyone can afford to make). Take it if you need to.
